text: France was represented by Roger Bens, with the song '"Femme dans ses rêves aussi", at the 1985 Eurovision Song Contest, which took place on 4 May in Gothenburg, Sweden. The song was chosen through a national final organised by broadcaster Antenne 2. ==Before Eurovision== === National final === The national final was held on 31 March 1985, hosted by Patrice Laffont and Catherine Ceylac. Fourteen songs took part with the winner chosen by a panel of TV viewers who were telephoned and asked to vote on the songs.ESC National Finals database 1985 {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Draw ! Artist ! Song ! Points ! Place |- |1 | align="left" |Les Jumelles | align="left" |"Notre Symphonie" |30 |11 |- style="font-weight:bold; background:gold;" | 2 | align="left" |Roger Bens | align="left" |"Femme dans ses rêves aussi" |215 |1 |- |3 | align="left" |Lucille Marciano | align="left" |"Pour ne pas oublier les hommes" |52 |9 |- |4 | align="left" |Julia Romagne | align="left" |"Dolly" |80 |6 |- |5 | align="left" |Florence Minet | align="left" |"Le cœur made in amour" |99 |4 |- |6 | align="left" |Florence Allora | align="left" |"C'est un sorcier" |63 |8 |- |7 | align="left" |Pascal Renard | align="left" |"Mary Jackson" |22 |12 |- |8 | align="left" |Sarah d'Armento | align="left" |"Zoom avant" |10 |14 |- |9 | align="left" |Henri de Vézins | align="left" |"Amour non-stop" |17 |13 |- |10 | align="left" |3+1 | align="left" |"Paris la France" |76 |7 |- |11 | align="left" |Betty Dian | align="left" |"Le jour où tu reviendras" |121 |2 |- |12 | align="left" |Françoise Robert | align="left" |"Only you, que vous" |103 |3 |- |13 | align="left" |Irka & Denis Pépin | align="left" |"Quelque chose me dit" |89 |5 |- |14 | align="left" |Nadine Séra | align="left" |"Un autre jour, une autre chance" |39 |10 |} == At Eurovision == On the night of the final Bens performed 6th in the running order, following Spain and preceding Turkey. At the close of voting "Femme dans ses rêves aussi" had received 56 points (including a maximum 12 from Greece), placing France 10th of the 19 entries. The French jury awarded its 12 points to Israel.ESC History - France 1985 === Points awarded by France === {| class="wikitable" |- |width=20% bgcolor="gold"|12 points|| |- |width=20% bgcolor="silver"|10 points|| |- |width=20% bgcolor="#CC9966"|8 points|| |- |width=20%|7 points|| |- |width=20%|6 points|| |- |width=20%|5 points|| |- |width=20%|4 points|| |- |width=20%|3 points|| |- |width=20%|2 points|| |- |width=20%|1 point|| |- |} === Points awarded to France === {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=5|Points awarded to France |- !width=20%|12 points !width=20%|10 points !width=20%|8 points !width=20%|7 points !width=20%|6 points |- | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | | valign="top" | | valign="top" | * |- !width=20%|5 points !width=20%|4 points !width=20%|3 points !width=20%|2 points !width=20%|1 point |- | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | * * | valign="top" | * * * * | valign="top" | * | valign="top" | * |- |} ==See also== *France in the Eurovision Song Contest *Eurovision Song Contest 1985 == References == Category:Countries in the Eurovision Song Contest 1985 Category:France in the Eurovision Song Contest Category:1985 in French music
